summary.seg: This fourteenth-century English Book of Hours is illustrated with several full-page portraits of saints at the beginning of the book, with the main text frequently accompanied by illuminated borders, marginalia and initials. The inclusion in the calendar of St Botulph (17 June) and St Hugh (17 November and his translation on 6 October, both written in red) suggests that the book was produced originally for use in the East Midlands, perhaps Lincoln. However, additions to the calendar in the early fourteenth century of Winwaloe (3 March) and Ethelbert (21 May) point to East Anglia - and the Litany (ff. 87r-92r has stronger Fenland (and in particular Diocese of Ely and Huntingdonshire) features: Edmund is placed high among the martyrs; Felix, Neot, Botulph, Ivo and Brendan among the confessors; and Etheldreda, Withburga and Sexburga among the virgins. These and other discrepancies suggest a development from Lincoln/East Midlands usage to Fenland usage, the miniatures and Calendar coming from the first stage of completion, and the remainder from the last, with the Litany dating to after 1320. The addition to the calendar of the names of the book's owners, Alice de Reydon, and John and Matilda Stranle, with their birth and/or death dates, tells a story of continual spiritual practice and personal devotion as the manuscript was passed from hand to hand.
This item was included in the Library’s 600th anniversary exhibition Lines of Thought: Discoveries that changed the world .

Revised and expanded by
Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

collation.p: The manuscript comprises 12 quires, formed of three principal codicological units: Quires 1-2 (suffrage miniatures and calendar), Quires 3-6 (Hours of the Virgin and Holy Spirit) and Quires 7-12 (Penitential Psalms, Litany, Office of the Dead). In two places, leaves have been lost from the volume and later replaced; these are described separately.
collation.formula: 16 212; 3-612; 710 814-2+2 (7th-8th leaves lost and later replaced) 910-1+1 (1st leaf lost and later replaced) 1010 118 128-3 (6th-8th leaves excised)

supportDesc.condition: Generally very good condition. Some staining on ff. 132v-135v. Some of the marginal borders, vine stems and grotesques have been lost through trimming of the edges of the leaves when the manuscript was rebound.

binding.p: Rebound by Douglas Cockerell and Son, Letchworth, December 1962. Red leather over wooden boards, sewn on three bands. Title and classmark tooled in gold on the spine.
Detached boards from eighteenth-century binding are preserved with the manuscript (but have not been digitised). Reverse brown calf, with centre panel and fleurons at the corners.
Damage to the fore-edge of f. i indicates the presence of two clasps on a former earlier binding.

acquisition.p: The manuscript is first recorded among the collections of Cambridge University Library in a catalogue compiled 1754-56 (now MS Oo.7.53).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript

msItem.title: Hymn (extract)
msItem.note: Me gardez cors e alme . de mal e dencumbrer. Fetes moy tre duz sire . bon fin aver. e par vostre grace de enfern eschaper e venir a la ioye ke sanz . fin deit durer amen

support.material: Parchment (disposition of hair and flesh sides uncertain)

list.item: Quire 814-2+2 (ff. 89-102: 7th and 8th leaves lost, after f. 94; later replaced by two leaves, now ff. 95-96)
Quire 910-1+1 (ff. 103-112: 1st leaf missing, before f. 104; later replaced by a single leaf, now f. 103)

layout.seg: Text ruled in ink, frame and line. Single columns, 16 lines to the page, written below top line.
Calendar ruled in ink, frame and line. Four columns, 33 lines, written below top line.

decoNote.p:
Twelve full-page suffrage miniatures, framed and on tooled gold or diapered pink and blue ground, in pairs at alternating openings before the Calendar. Their style is associated with the Queen Mary Psalter workshop ( London, British Library, Royal MS 2.B.vii). The same artist worked on a Psalter made for a patron in the Norwich diocese, which later passed to Peterborough Abbey ( Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 53).
1v: woman (perhaps intended to represent the commissioner or an early owner of the manuscript) kneeling in veneration before a sainted archbishop. The archbishop (?St Thomas, ?St Edmund) was altered from being a bishop (perhaps originally St Hugh, as in the Calendar) by the substitution of a cross for a crozier and the addition of a pallium. The arms of the Reymes family also appear to have been added to the woman's mantle.
2r: St Catherine and St Margaret
3v: St George
4r: St Christopher
5v: Annunciation
6r: Nativity
7v: Resurrection
8r: Ascension
9v: Coronation of Virgin
10r: Christ in Majesty, with Evangelists' symbols
11v: Virgin and Child
12r: Crucifixion
12v Rough drawing of St John the Baptist with Lamb, probably added in the 14th century.

Calendar miniatures comprising labours of the months and zodiac signs, on punched gold ground under canopies, in outer margins. Executed by a second artist, related to that of the prefatory suffrage miniatures.
13r: January: Janus feasting; Aquarius
13v: February: man warming himself by fire; Pisces
14r: March: pruning; Aries
14v: April: hawking; Taurus
15r: May: Maying; Gemini
15v: June: mowing; Cancer
16r: July: reaping; Leo
16v: August: threshing; Virgo
17r: September: harvesting grapes; Libra
17v: October: sowing; Scorpio
18r: November: beating for acorns; Sagittarius
18v: December: slaughtering pig; Capricorn

Border decoration of rich foliage in blue, red, green and gold extending from letter finials and forming full or partial frames, with marginal grotesques and drolleries. The border decoration relates to the Howard Psalter possibly made for John Fitton of Wiggenhall St German's, Norfolk (London, British Library, Arundel MS 83, part I), the Gorleston Psalter (London, British Library, Add. MS 49622), and the fourteenth-century part of the Alfonso Psalter (London, British Library, Add. MS 24686).

On f. 19r, heraldic shields suspended from vine sprays projecting inwards from the border, showing the coats of arms of:
England (gules, three lions passant guardant in pale or)
Unknown (shield defaced, but formerly azure)
Aymer de Valence, earl of Pembroke (c. 1270-1324) Pembroke, Aymer de Valence, ca. 1270-1324, earl of
A further three heraldic shields were once included, suspended from corresponding vine sprays projecting outwards from the border, however all have since been wholly or almost entirely cropped.
Also on this page, a decorated initial contains the arms of the Reymes family (gules a cross or engraved or) .

19r: at the opening of the Hours of the Virgin: a nine-line historiated initial D, executed by a third artistic hand. The figure style of this artist is related to the Bardolf-Vaux Psalter (London, Lambeth Palace Library, MS 233). Letter formed of interlaced vine stems, on coloured ground divided into quarters, formed alternately of red or blue chequered patterns. Contains scene depicting a woman (perhaps intended to represent the commissioner or an early owner of the manuscript) praying to seated Virgin and Child, on punched gold ground.

79r: at the opening of the Penitential Psalms, a seven-line historiated initial D, executed by a fourth artistic hand. Letter formed of interlaced vine stems, on coloured ground divided into quarters, formed alternately of red or blue chequered patterns, which extend into the interstice of the letter. Contains Christ in Majesty, seated and holding a book, on a burnished, oval-shaped gold ground.

Three- to six-line figural initials, filled with foliated and zoomorphic spirals, on tooled gold ground, to the Hours of the Virgin (ff. 25v, 37v, 41r, 43v, 45v, 48r, 52r) and at the beginning of the Hours of the Holy Spirit (f. 68r).
Two- to seven-line initials in blue, filled with foliage, human heads or grotesques, on burnished gold ground.
Four-line initials in blue in the Calendar, filled with red and green foliage, on gold ground.
One-line initials at the beginning of verses, alternating in gold and blue, with contrasting blue and red penwork flourishing.
Line-fillers comprising vegetation, geometric and zoomorphic designs in blue or turquoise and red, some forming frames.

note.p: Under the illustration on 4r, a Latin collect has been added.
On folios 61r-74r, the rubrics have been erased and written over in French.
Folios 95r-96v were added later, written in a 16th-century hand, presumably due to loss of these folios in the original.

Additions have been made to the calendar, 13r-18v, by several hands dating variously to the early fourteenth to the fifteenth century. These include obits and saints' days (see Provenance for further details) and notes by two hands that mark the beginning and end of the 'dies caniculares' (or 'dog days'; 16r, 17r), the hottest period of the year.

history.origin:
First quarter of the 14th century (perhaps not before 1320; not after 1323), England.
The manuscript may be datable to after 1320: since Thomas Becket is among the martyrs, the Thomas among the confessors in the Litany (f. 90r) is probably Thomas de Cantilupe Thomas, de Cantelupe, Saint, approximately 1218-1282, who was canonized in 1320.
For explanation of the terminus post quem non, see Provenance.
The manuscript may have been made in East Anglia, as were other manuscripts with which it bears artistic affinities (see Decoration).

provenance.p: Probably owned by Alice de Reydon Reydon, Alice de, née Reymes, wife of Robert de Reydon. Her obituary is added to the Calendar in a contemporary hand, on the 5th July (fol. 16r): 'Obitus Alicie de Reidon anno domini Mo ccco x...'. The year is uncertain, but must be after 1310 (the first limb of 'x' is visible; if any number followed, it has been cropped) but before 1323: the Inquisitions Post Mortem held in that year on Alice's husband gives the name of his widow as Margaret. The manuscript may have been produced for her prior to her marriage, since her family's coat of arms features on f. 19r. The female figures on ff. 1v and 19r may have been intended to represent her: the mantle of the former figure has had the Reymes family coat of arms painted over it (the cross or has been divided in two vertically and painted along each edge).

listBibl.bibl: Calendar of Inquisitions Post Mortem, vol. 6, Edward II (1910), no. 419

provenance.p: Two early fourteenth century hands have inserted additional feast days that confirm an East Anglian provenance: St Winwaloe ('Sancti Winewaloei') on 3rd March (f. 14r) and St Ethelbert on 21st May (usually 20th; f. 15r). Winwaloe is more commonly patron saint of foundations in the south-west, his reputed homeland, however a Benedictine priory dedicated to him was founded at Wereham in 1199; it was later dissolved in 1321 and given to nearby abbey of West Dereham.

Stranle family: the birth dates of John Stranle (17th February) (f. 13v) and Matilda Stranle (9th April) (f. 14v) were inserted in the calendar, by perhaps the same hand. Another, later hand glossed the entry for John Stranle with the year of his birth: 'anno Regis Ricardi secundi quarto' (1380/81).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.17, ff. 95-96

extent.seg: Bifolium, added to replace two leaves lost after f. 94, but providing different text to that lost.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line. Single columns, 16 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in an uneven textura quadrata of the 16th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.17, f. 103

extent.seg: Single leaf, added to replace a leaf lost after f. 102.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line. Single columns, 16 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in textura quadrata, in brown ink. The hand is different to that responsible for the rest of the text (compare the execution of marks above the letter i and the occasionally rounded execution of lower serifs).

decoNote.p: Two-line puzzle initial in red and blue, with internal void decoration, enclosing animal grosteque in red ink, and supporting marginal flourishing in red and blue ink.
One-line initials, alternating in red or blue, with contrasting penwork infill and marginal flourishing in blue or red.
Line-fillers comprising geometric and zoomorphic designs, executed in red and blue.
